One of the best sim racing experiences you can get, even years later.

Assetto Corsa might be getting old, but it‚Äôs aged like fine wine - especially once you dive into the modding scene. The base game alone is solid but a bit barebones by today‚Äôs standards. The real magic happens once you install Content Manager and Custom Shaders Patch (CSP). Those two completely transform the game -better lighting, weather, physics tweaks, smoother performance, and tons of quality-of-life features. It honestly feels like a new title after that.

Then you‚Äôve got the mods - cars, tracks, visuals, sound packs, everything you can imagine. The community support is insane, and there‚Äôs something for every kind of driver, from casual track day enthusiasts to full-on sim racers. You can go from drifting in Japan to racing GT3s at Spa, or even just cruising through city maps at sunset.

If you‚Äôre playing on a controller, don‚Äôt worry - there are some amazing Gamepad FX scripts that completely change how Assetto Corsa feels without a wheel.

For grip racing, there‚Äôs Advanced Gamepad Assist, which smooths out steering, reduces twitchiness, and gives you way more precision when braking and cornering. It makes racing with a controller feel natural and consistent.

For drifting, there‚Äôs a different script called A7 Assist, designed specifically for smoother countersteering. It makes it much easier to catch slides and hold long drifts without the car snapping or feeling unpredictable.

Both are absolute game-changers depending on your driving style.

Performance-wise, it runs great on most modern PCs, and the visuals can look stunning once you tune everything with CSP and a good graphics preset (would definitely check out Pure if I were you)

All in all, Assetto Corsa is one of those games that grows with you - the deeper you go, the better it gets. It‚Äôs not perfect out of the box, but with the right setup, it‚Äôs easily one of the best and most flexible sim racing platforms ever made.

Assetto Corsa is showing its age in some areas. It lacks a few modern sim-racing essentials such as a built-in ranking system or proper online matchmaking. However, none of that overshadows the reason this game is still played a decade later: the driving experience is outstanding.

Cars feel alive and responsive, and the handling remains one of the most authentic in the genre. Even after ten years, the physics are still among the best available. Every lap delivers that satisfying feedback where the car talks to you through the track, the force feedback, and the subtle shift in grip.

On top of that, Assetto Corsa offers full mod support, which continues to extend its life far beyond what most racing titles manage. Modding should always be standard on PC, and here it shines.

I hope Assetto Corsa Evo will bring modern features and infrastructure to the table, while keeping the core driving experience that made the original special. If it can achieve that, it might just set the bar again.

Assetto Corsa is a solid simracer, but with it's own drawbacks. What you should understand before buying is that AI in this game is absolute garbage that sticks to predefined racing lines with very little situational awareness. But where this game shines is in hotlapping, casual driving and multiplayer racing (so basically everywhere except for singleplayer experience with AI).
The biggest upside of this game is its modding community. It's extremely active, you can drive pretty much any car you want on pretty much any track you want, but with some caveats (don't always expect dev quality in mods). But even without mods, I think it provides a good simracing/driving experience.

I absolutely love this game. I recently got really into F1, and I have always loved racing, but never knew where to begin. This game drops you in, there's no free roam no story, just set up a race and start driving. Here are some pros and cons about the game that you should know before buying.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[olist]
[*]This game is one of (if not) the cheapest racing games that have realistic racing and racing physics. It strives on track, but it's fine on rally courses, and karting tracks too. I know the newest F1 game is 5x the price of this on sale and for $4.99 the game gives you so much. I do recommend getting the Ultimate Edition, as it will give you the most out of what you want, and for less than $20 (on sale) it's a steal.
[*] Has Good Graphics, and if you want more you can use mods to better the lighting, but it's not built for it so the game may crash.
[*]Super Customizable. You can race anything, you could race F1 with GT3 cars, drive karts on GT Cup tracks, etc. You have so much control over your system/game and your races.
[*]AC's Tracks are great! and you can find good mods for any track they don't have. It helps with learning a track before a race you are going to watch. You can try and set your fastest lap and see it in relation to the real drivers.
[*]I'm not a racer, but the physics feel and act very well. You 
[/olist]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[olist]
[*]It's not great by it's self, You won't be able to easily race a custom race without mods. If you want to race F1, Nascar, any newer class or car models (Like Porsche 911 GT3 RS or any 992, etc.), or things like rally you have to use a mod manager and download mods.
[*]Not the best for multiplayer/online, if you want to play with friends or others it's just not the best. The AI is pretty good, and very customizable with the difficulty, sometimes (mainly with mods) ai can act weirdly or not be the best, but overall it's pretty good.
[*]Not good for Keyboard players. You need a wheel to have fun with this game. But, with a cheap wheel it's still feels good and realistic.
[/olist]
[i][Note: This is not the full list of Pros and Cons just somethings to think about][/i]

Drift sim? Yes. F1 sim? Absolutely. Drag racing? Works. Want to race Thomas the Tank Engine against a Lamborghini? Don‚Äôt ask why, just install the mod with Content Manager.

Even Max Verstappen said he still uses AC with mods for training. If it‚Äôs good enough for a world champion, it‚Äôs good enough for my sleep schedule to suffer.

I think that in the sim racing community this game will become a legend and it will always be remembered.

Assetto Corsa is an absolute must-play if you own a steering wheel! The detailed physics engine, laser-scanned tracks, and deep car setup options come alive when paired with proper wheel hardware, delivering an authentic and deeply rewarding driving simulation. With a wheel, every nuance of the car‚Äôs handling is felt, making each lap an immersive experience.

However, trying to play Assetto Corsa with a gamepad feels frustrating and limiting. The precise control required for braking, throttle, and steering is difficult with analog sticks and triggers, often making the game nearly unplayable for all but the most casual racing fans. Assetto Corsa truly shines with a wheel; anything else misses the soul of the simulation. If you‚Äôre serious about racing games, do yourself a favor and experience it as it was meant to be: with a wheel!
